CO₂ hydrogenation is a structure-sensitive reaction, producing a diverse range of products based on the structure of catalysts. In this study, we present a catalyst Mo-ZrO2 for CO2 hydrogenation and observed the products vary among CO, CH4, and CH3OH as Mo changes in its loading and local environment. Kinetic studies reveal that increasing Mo loading amplifies hydrogenation ability of the catalyst while simultaneously reducing CO2 adsorption on ZrO2. Specifically, Mo loadings under 10 wt% result in Mo integration into ZrO2 support, forming a Mo-O-Zr structure. Conversely, a higher Mo loading leads to the formation of Zr(MoO4)2 clusters on ZrO2 support. The Mo5⁺-Ov-Zr structure, formed in Mo-doped ZrO2 during reduction pretreatment, emerges as an active site for methanol synthesis. In contrast, metallic Mo formed from the reduction of Zr(MoO4)2 clusters loaded on ZrO2 is responsible for methane formation. The evolution of the surface structure from Mo-O-Zr structure to Zr(MoO4)2 clusters on ZrO2 as Mo loading changes, resulting in alterations in the number of active sites for methanol synthesis and methanation, consequently leading to variations in product distribution. Graphical Abstract Keywords Active site Selectivity Mechanism Mo ZrO2 Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In recent years, Carbon Capture, Utilization, and Storage (CCUS) has gained considerable attention due to concerns about the greenhouse effect [1–5]. Transforming CO₂ into valuable chemicals through catalytic hydrogenation has emerged as a promising avenue. Metal-oxide has been proven as an effective catalyst protocol to drive this reaction [6–12], and the interaction between the metal and the oxide as well as their structures have been found a significant impact on the activity and selectivity [13–20]. For instance, Strong Metal Support Interaction (SMSI) was observed on Ru/In2O3, where the partially reduced In2O3 encapsulates Ru sites, suppressing the methanation reaction and promoting methanol production [12]. The dispersion of Cu on ZrO2 changes as its loading amount changes in the Cu-ZrO2 catalysts, in turn alternating product distribution. Cu1O3 structural unit forms in the catalyst at low Cu loading, which orients towards 100% methanol selectivity. With the increase of Cu loading, Cu particles form and alter the methanol synthesis reaction to the RWGS reaction [21]. The formation of Zn-O-Zr structure on the ZnO-ZrO2 catalysts was found to be an active site for H2 dissociation and stabilizing carbon-oxygen species, thus promoting catalytic high-performance synthesis of methanol [22,23]. Oxygen vacancies (Ov) in reducible supports also play an important role in the reaction [11,24–28]. The Ov in the interface between Cu/TiO2 facilitates the activation of the CO2 and the formation of *HCOO, thus promoting methanol formation [29]. Similarly, Liu et al. found that the reaction rate of CO2 is strongly dependent on the oxygen vacancy formation energy, and more oxygen vacancies enhance the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol over Pd/CeO2 catalysts [24]. Mo-based catalysts, prevalent in petroleum refining and syngas-to-alcohol conversions [30], hold promise for efficient CO₂ conversion due to their unique pro-oxidant properties [31] Notably, the variation of TiO2 crystalline in Mo/TiO2 results in different product distribution. The introduction of Mo improves the H2 dissociation properties of the support. TiO2 support consists of rutile nanorods with highly dispersed Mo4+, resulting in the highest methanol activity [32]. MoS2 undergoes a reduction process that generates abundant sulfur vacancies, facilitating the conversion of CO2 to methanol at low temperatures [33]. The reduced MoO3 with oxygen vacancies, i.e. MoO3−x, which migrate to the surface of Ru nanoparticles and form encapsulated structure Ru@MoO3−x, leading to a transformation of the product from CH4 to CO [20]. Gaining insights into Mo local environment and its associated performance is crucial for modulating product distribution in CO₂ hydrogenation. In this study, we synthesized a Mo-ZrO2 catalyst, adjusting its exposed surface structure to elucidate the impact of Mo-ZrO2 interactions and surface configurations on activity and selectivity. We found that the evolution of the surface structure from Mo-O-Zr structure to Zr(MoO4)2 cluster on ZrO2 as the Mo loading changes, varies the products in CO, CH3OH, and CH4. Combining spectroscopies, electron microscopy, chemisorption, and kinetics analysis, the Mo5+-Ov-Zr structure is found to be an active site for methanol formation in the reaction and the formation of Zr(MoO4)2 cluster loaded on ZrO2 facilitates methane formation. The surface structure and the performance relationship of the catalyst Mo-ZrO2 was also discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts ZrO2, MoO3, Zr(MoO4)2, and Mo-ZrO2 catalysts with different Mo loadings were synthesized by hard template method. In a typical synthesis of 10 wt% Mo-ZrO2, 0.2347 g of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, and 4 g of Zr(NO3)4·5H2O were dissolved in 15 mL of deionized water and stirred at 70 ℃ for 20 min until the solution was clarified. 1.5 g of BP 2000 (CABOT BLACK PEARLS 2000) was slowly added to the solution and the solution was dried overnight at 60 ℃ in a vacuum oven to obtain the powder. The powder was further calcined at 500 ℃ for 5 h with a ramping rate of 2 °C·min−1 in the air in a muffle furnace to get 10 wt% Mo-ZrO2 (denoted as 10MZ). Similarly, catalysts with different Mo loadings were prepared and denoted xMZ (x = 1, 5, 20, and 40), where x represents the nominal loading of molybdenum. 10 wt% Mo-ZrO2_IP was prepared on a ZrO2 carrier synthesized by the hard template method by incipient wetness impregnation, using (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O as the precursor. After impregnation, the catalysts were dried at 100 ℃ for one night. The catalysts were further calcined at 500 ℃ for 5 h with a ramping rate of 2 °C·min−1 in the air in a muffle furnace to get 10 wt% Mo-ZrO2_IP, denoted as 10MZ_IP. 2.2 Catalyst evaluation A straight stainless-steel plug-flow fixed-bed reactor was used for catalyst evaluation. Typically, the catalysts were pressed and sieved to 40–60 mesh, 200 mg of catalyst was diluted by 450 mg of SiC and then loaded to the reactor. The catalysts were reduced at 500 ℃ for 2 h in an H2 gas (30 mL·min−1) prior to the reaction. The reactor was then cooled down to reaction temperature under an H2 flow (30 mL·min−1). After that, the reactant gas (H2/CO2/N2 = 3:1:1) was fed into the reactor. The catalytic performance was evaluated from 225 ℃ to 275 ℃, 30 bar, with a constant flow of 36 mL/min. The gaseous hourly space velocity (GHSV) was fixed at 10,800 mL·g−1·h−1 . Similarly, kinetics analyses were conducted in the temperature range of 220 ℃ to 280 °C, at a total pressure of 30 bar and a gaseous hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 9600 mL·g−1·h−1 . The effluent was monitored through an online gas chromatograph (Techcomp, GC-7980) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Chromatographic columns were equipped with a 5 A molecular sieve column in series with a 13X molecular sieve column and a Porapak Q column. N2 was used as an internal standard gas to correct for changes in volume before and after the reaction. The CO2 conversion ( X CO 2 ), selectivity (Si, i=CO, CH4, and CH3OH), and space−time yield (STYi) were calculated based on the following equations: (1) X CO 2 = n CO 2 , in − n CO 2 , out n CO 2 , in × 100 % (2) S i = n i n CO + n CH 4 + n CH 3 OH × 100 % (3) STY i = n CO 2 , in × X CO 2 × S i × 1000 m cat × M i (4) CH 3 OH TOF = STY CH 3 OH × M Mo Mo loading × 1000 × M CH 3 OH where ni and Mi refer to the molar flow rate and the molar mass of species i, respectively, and mcat is the weight of the packed catalyst. 2.3 Catalyst characterization XRD patterns are recorded on a Rigaku Smart Lab 9 kW diffractometer, using a nickel-filtered Cu Kα radiation at a scanning rate of 10°·min−1 and a step size of 8° between 5° to 80°. The tube voltage and current used are 45 kV and 200 mA, respectively. The average grain size of the samples was calculated using Scherrer's formula. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was tested on the VDSorb-91i chemisorption instrument, typically as follows: 0.1 g catalyst was weighed into a U-shaped quartz tube, pretreated at 150 °C for 1 h in an Ar atmosphere to remove water and then brought to room temperature. 10% H2/Ar mixture with a flow rate of 15 mL·min−1 was introduced and the temperature was increased to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C·min−1, and the H2 consumption was measured with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) was tested on the VDSorb-91i chemisorption instrument, typically as follows: weighed 0.1 g of pre-reduction passivated catalyst, loaded into a U-shaped quartz tube, pretreated at 500 °C for 0.5 h in a 10% H2/Ar gas mixture with a flow rate of 15 mL·min−1. Then lowered to room temperature, adsorbed with CO2 gas for 1 h until saturation, then switched to Ar gas for purging, ramped up to 800 °C at 10 °C·min−1, and detected the amount of CO2 desorbed by TCD. N2 physisorption isotherms were measured on a Micromeritics TriStar II 3020 analyzer. Samples were first degassed under vacuum at 120 °C for 6 h and subsequently tested at liquid nitrogen temperature (−196 °C). The specific surface area was calculated by the BET method, the total pore volume was measured from the adsorption volume at a relative pressure of 0.95, and the pore size distribution was calculated by the BJH method. The Raman spectroscopy was performed using a Witec confocal micro-Raman spectrometer with a 532 nm diode chestnut-pumped solid-state laser as the light source and a sampling time of 10 seconds. The UV-Raman spectroscopy was performed using a homemade Raman spectrometer with a 320 nm diode chestnut-pumped solid-state laser as the light source and a sampling time of 600 s. The UV–vis diffuse reflectance absorption spectroscopy was performed on JASCO-V650 and JASCO-V550 spectrometers manufactured by JASCO, Japan, equipped with an integrating sphere device for solid powder sample characterization. The 1, 5, 20, and 40MZ were performed on JASCO-V650. The ZrO2, 10MZ, 10MZ_IP, and MoO3 were performed on JASCO-V550. The acquisition wavelength range was 190–800 nm, the acquisition speed was 100 nm·min−1, and the acquisition step was 5 nm. Solid samples were baseline calibrated using BaSO4 as the standard sample before each test. The band gap of the catalysts was calculated by the Tauc method. The X-ray photoelectron spectra were conducted on a Shimadzu KRATOS AXIS SUPRAT spectrometer, using Al Ka (hv = 1486.6 eV) radiation source. Prior to testing, the catalysts were subjected to in-situ hydrogen reduction for 1 h at 500 °C. All spectra were calibrated with the C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV. The microstructure photographs of the samples were collected under a Talos F200X transmission electron microscope from FEI, USA, with an accelerating voltage of 300 kV. The samples were dispersed in an ethanol solution and then dropped onto a clean nickel grid prior to the observation. The energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) element mapping images were obtained at 200 kV to investigate the elemental distribution. 3 Results and discussion The catalytic activities of the catalysts Mo-ZrO2 prepared by different methods and loadings and ZrO2 are shown in Fig. 1. The sample ZrO2 (0 wt% Mo loading) exhibits a low CO2 conversion and gaseous CO is found to be the observed sole product. Once the 1 wt% Mo is added onto ZrO2, the conversion of CO2 is significantly improved, and the products move from CO only to CH4, CH3OH, and CO. As the loading of Mo increases, the CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity increases and reaches the maximum at 10 wt% Mo loading. After that, both the conversion of CO2 and methanol selectivity decreases, but the methane selectivity starts increasing. A further increase in Mo loading from 20 wt% to 40 wt% does not change the activity and the selectivity. However, further increasing the loading of Mo to 100 wt%, i.e. MoO3, the selectivity to methanol decreases to zero and leaves the CO and CH4 in the products. A comparison of the catalytic activities of 10MZ and 10MZ_IP revealed that the catalyst synthesized by the hard template method improves CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity. For the 10MZ catalyst, an experiment was conducted to investigate the effect of temperature on its catalytic performance. The reaction temperature was varied from 225 to 300 °C, and the results are presented in Figure S2. It can be observed that as the reaction temperature increases, both the CO2 conversion and the space-time yield (STY) of methanol increase. However, the selectivity of methanol decreases with the increase in temperature. Furthermore, the stability of the catalyst was evaluated through a 100-hour stability test, and the results are depicted in Figure S3. The catalyst exhibited good stability over the test duration, indicating its potential for long-term use in the reaction. The Raman spectrum of the catalyst after the reaction is shown in Figure S4. We found that the Raman peak at 970 cm−1 of the used catalyst was shifted to near 1000 cm−1. This shift is because the Zr(MoO4)2 is reduced during the reaction, and re-oxidized to form the MoO3 particle once exposed to air [34]. The unchanged positions of the other Raman peaks indicate that the catalyst surface structure remains stable during the reaction. To investigate the cause of the divergent selectivity, a measurement of surface area and pore size was first conducted and the results are summarized in Table 1. The specific surface area of ZrO2 synthesized through the hard template method is 66 m2/g, and the loading of 10 wt% Mo (10MZ_IP) by impregnation method does not decrease it much showing 62 m2/g. Intriguingly, using the hard template method to introduce less than 20 wt% Mo to ZrO2 leads to an increase in the specific surface area, which can be caused by the promotion of mesopore formation demonstrated by the increase of pore volume shown in Table 1 [35]. When the Mo content was elevated to 40 wt%, the specific surface area started to decrease. However, the specific surface area changes from 62 m2/g for 10MZ_IP to 103 m2/g for 10MZ cannot interpret product distribution change, especially the 6-times enhancement of methanol yield for these two catalysts. The changes in activity and selectivity must be associated with the surface structure change or new species formation induced by Mo. Additionally, Zhou's prior work supports this hypothesis, revealing that Mo introduction into ZrO2 can lead to lattice doping, potentially enhancing the specific surface area [36]. This concept may also apply to our observations, prompting us to extend our investigation with UV–vis Diffuse Reflectance Spectroscopy (DRS) to probe the interactions between Mo and ZrO2. Fig. 2a shows the band gaps of the catalysts as determined by the Tauc method, employing UV–vis (DRS) data (refer to Figure S6). Pristine ZrO2 exhibits a band gap of approximately 4.9 eV. The addition of Mo narrows this band gap significantly, yielding a value of 2.9 eV, which is remarkably lower than that of MoO3 (around 3.1 eV). This observation suggests that Mo does not merely form MoO3; rather, it may integrate into the ZrO2 crystal lattice, potentially creating doped defect energy levels or novel Mo species. In order to elucidate the relationship between structure and performance of the catalysts, the crystal phase was characterized by XRD, and the results are shown in Fig. 2b. The synthesized ZrO2 comprises a mixed phase of monoclinic (PDF #37–1484) and tetragonal phases (PDF #50–1089). However, catalysts with Mo loadings from 1 to 20 wt% (1MZ-20MZ) predominantly exhibit the tetragonal phases. The monoclinic phase ZrO2 is the thermodynamic stable phase at higher temperature [37], so this result indicates the addition of Mo suppresses the phase transformation of ZrO2 from tetragonal to monoclinic in this synthesis. This phenomenon was also observed on ZrO2 supported Cu [21]. As the loading of Mo increases to 40 wt%, a diffraction peak at 23.2° appears, it is attributed to (112) of Zr(MoO4)2 (PDF #38-1466), instead of forming MoO3 (via comparison with the XRD pattern of MoO3). The Zr(MoO4)2 species is also observed in 10MZ_IP, but absent in 10MZ. This indicates that the impregnation method leads to bigger clusters of Zr(MoO4)2 on ZrO2, while the hard template method leads to a highly dispersed Mo species on ZrO2 as XRD is not very sensitive to the surface of the particle. Raman spectroscopy, known for its enhanced surface sensitivity compared to XRD, was employed for a more detailed investigation of the surface structures of catalysts [38–42]. Fig. 3a-b present the Raman spectra of various Mo-ZrO2 catalysts, excited by visible and UV lasers at 532 nm and 320 nm, respectively. The comparison between UV Raman and Vis Raman spectra can figure out the surface species as the UV Raman is more sensitive to the surface region [37,40–42]. In the ZrO2 spectra, the bands observed at 269, 312, 472, and 556 cm−1 correspond to the vibrational mode of tetragonal ZrO2 (t-ZrO2), specifically Eg, B1g, Ag and Ag, in that order. Additionally, the peak at 377 cm−1 and 634 cm−1 are ascribed to the vibrational mode Bg of monoclinic ZrO2 (m-ZrO2) [37,43]. Once Mo is introduced to ZrO2, the stretching vibration of M=O of MoO4 2- and Mo8O26 4- can be observed at 820 cm−1 and 970 cm−1, respectively [39]. These bands could be caused by the formation of MoO3 or Zr(MoO4)2 [44]. An interesting observation can be found by comparing visible Raman spectra with UV Raman spectra. The Raman peak of ZrO2 at 634 cm−1 can be seen for Mo-ZrO2 catalyst with Mo loading up to 20 wt% (1MZ to 20MZ) in visible Raman spectra, while in UV Raman spectra it can be found when the Mo loading is below 20 wt%. It is clearly observed that the catalyst has strong absorption to 320 nm light but barely absorbs 532 nm light from Fig. 2a, so most Raman scatterings from the bulk of the catalysts are absorbed when using 320 nm laser and cannot escape and be collected by the detector, but it can do so when using 532 nm laser. With this understanding, the above comparison suggests that with the rise of Mo loading, the surface of ZrO2 is gradually covered by Mo species, evidenced by the gradually weakened signal of ZrO2 in the UV Raman spectra. When the Mo loading reaches 20 wt%, the band at 634 cm−1 assigned to ZrO2 is barely observed, so we speculate that the surface of ZrO2 is almost covered by Zr(MoO4)2 clusters, forming a core/shell-like structure. And, this shell becomes thicker as the Mo increases to 40 wt%. This could be the reason for the similarity of the activity and selectivity exhibited by the two catalysts, 20MZ and 40MZ. While for the 10MZ_IP catalyst, a Raman peak attributed to typical fingerprint vibration modes of MoO3 at 335 cm−1 appeared on the UV Raman spectrum. [45] This suggests that a poor dispersion of Mo species on the 10MZ_IP catalysts formed MoO3 or Zr(MoO4)2 clusters on ZrO2 support. To elucidate the surface species as well as structural information of Mo-ZrO2 catalysts across different loadings and synthesis techniques, representatives 10MZ, 40MZ, and 10MZ_IP were subjected to HRTEM analysis. Fig. 4a-c display TEM images of three catalysts 10MZ, 40MZ, and 10MZ_IP catalysts. The mean particle size of 10MZ measures at 4 nm, considerably smaller than the 7 nm particles of both 40MZ and 10MZ_IP. This observed trend aligns with the results obtained from XRD analysis using the Scheller equation, indicating particle sizes of 5 nm for 10MZ, 9 nm for 40MZ, and 8 nm for 10MZ_IP. HRTEM images presented in Fig. 4d-f exhibit distinct lattice spacings for the three catalysts. In the case of the 10MZ catalyst, the calculation of lattice spacing reveals one observed lattice stripe at 0.295 nm, corresponding to the (011) crystal plane of t-ZrO2, and another lattice spacing of 0.316 nm, corresponding to the (211) crystal plane of Zr(MoO4)2. In contrast, for both 40MZ and 10MZ_IP, in addition to the lattice stripes corresponding to the (011) crystal plane of t-ZrO2 observed, lattice stripes corresponding to the (−111) crystal plane of MoO2 can also be observed. The formation of MoO2 could be caused by the reduction of a large cluster of Zr(MoO4)2 which is observed in XRD. Furthermore, Energy-Dispersive X-ray (EDX) elemental mapping, illustrated in Fig. 4g-i for 10MZ, indicates a congruent distribution of Mo and Zr, implying a homogeneous dispersion of Mo species on the ZrO2 support [36]. In contrast, the agglomeration of Mo is observed on the 40MZ and 10MZ_IP catalysts in the EDX elemental mapping images (Figure S7), which is consistent with the results of XRD. These outcomes collectively suggest that catalysts crafted via the hard template method possess a more uniformly dispersed Mo species, fostering the formation of Mo-O-Zr structural domains as opposed to the formation of surface Zr(MoO4)2 clusters, particularly when the Mo loading does not exceed 10 wt%. Kinetic analyses were performed to understand the impact of Mo species as its loading change on the reaction. To negate the effects of internal diffusion, we pelletized the catalysts, and external diffusion was mitigated by modulating the linear velocity, as detailed in Figure S8. As shown in Fig. 5a, a strong positive dependence on H2 is observed across all MZ catalysts concerning methanol synthesis, with the H2 order commencing at 1.1 for the 1MZ catalyst and diminishing to 0.2 upon increasing the Mo loading to 40 wt%. Unlike the H2 order, the CO2 order shows an increasing trend with the increase of Mo loading. The CO2 order for 1MZ is about 0.2 much smaller than the H2 order, but it increases as the Mo loading increases and reaches 0.5 over the H2 order at 0.2 for 40MZ. It suggests that the adsorption of CO2 is weakened as the Mo loading increases. Combined with the above characterizations on structure, it is supposed that the excessive Zr(MoO4)2 clusters covered the ZrO2 leading to a limitation of the adsorption of CO2. As shown in Fig. 5b-c, for the methanation reaction, the H2 reaction orders decrease slowly compared to that in methanol formation, while the CO2 reaction orders do not change significantly and are all close to zero. For the RWGS reaction, H2 reaction orders are similar to that in the methanation reaction, whereas the CO2 reaction orders show a positive reaction level at 0.5. The apparent activation energies of the different catalysts are listed in Table S1. It is clear show that on all catalysts, the apparent activation energy (Ea) for the methanol formation is 70±10 kJ/mol, that for CO formation is 90±5 kJ/mol, and that for methane formation is 110±5 kJ/mol. The increasing order in activation energy (Ea(CH3OH)＜Ea(CO)＜Ea(CH4)) suggests that CO could be the intermediate for methane formation but not the intermediate for methanol formation. This speculation agrees well with the reaction mechanism previously reported. [46–53] We summarized the key reaction steps of the methanation (blue pathway), methanol synthesis reactions (red pathway), and RWGS reaction (green pathway) in Fig. 5d. CO2 is initially adsorbed onto the catalysts and subsequently hydrogenated to form *COOH and *HCOO intermediates. The hydrogenation of *COOH yields *CO, which can either desorb as gaseous CO or undergo further hydrogenation to methane. However, methanol synthesis follows an alternative route involving the *HCOO intermediates, which interacts with H* to produce HCOOH*, H2COOH*, CH2O*, and CH3O* intermediates sequentially, culminating in methanol formation. This pathway progresses independent of CO* as an intermediate, aligning with our kinetic analysis-based conjectures. The interaction with CO2 as the function of Mo loading on ZrO2 was further studied by temperature-programmed CO2 desorption shown in Figure S11. On ZrO2 catalysts, Zr sites were found to be active for CO2 adsorption [22], and MoO3 as an acidic oxide exhibits a weak interaction with CO2 [54]. The catalysts have two desorption peaks, one is below 300 °C and the other one is at 400–600 °C. The low-temperature desorption peak below 300 °C represents a weakly basic site on the catalyst surface associated with -OH groups [55], while the high-temperature desorption peak represents a moderately basic site on the catalyst surface, which can be attributed to metal-oxygen pairs (e.g. Zr-O) [56]. When the Mo loading is below 10 wt%, the CO2 adsorption at low temperature was enhanced showing a shift of desorption peak to higher temperatures. It was found that the introduction of Cu promotes the formation of oxygen vacancies, consequently increasing the concentration of hydroxyl groups on the catalyst surface [7]. In this context, we believe that Mo serves a similar role. With further increase of Mo loading to and above 10 wt%, the interaction of the catalysts with CO2 at low temperatures is weakened. Based on the Raman spectroscopy findings mentioned above, it becomes evident that the surface of ZrO2 enveloped by Zr(MoO4)2 clusters when the Mo loadings exceed 20 wt%, which owing to the acidic nature of Zr(MoO4)2, weakens the interaction with CO2 at low temperatures. Unlike 10MZ, the CO2 desorption peak of 10MZ_IP, synthesized via the impregnation method, shifts toward higher temperatures. This shift can be attributed to partial coverage of the ZrO2 surface by larger Zr(MoO4)2 clusters, as indicated by the aforementioned Raman spectra. H2-TPR was used to investigate the changes of Zr(MoO4)2 clusters and Mo-O-Zr structure under the H2 environment and the results are shown in Fig. 6a. For ZrO2, the peak of H2 consumption at 615 °C is attributed to the reduction of ZrO2. As 1 wt% Mo is doped to ZrO2, the peak of H2 consumption shifts to a lower temperature at 560 °C, and further shifts to 490–470 °C for 5MZ and 10MZ. It was found the dopant or foreign cations can lower the reduction temperature of oxide [57–59], so these peaks are attributed to the reduction of Mo-O-Zr structure, leading to a lower oxidation state of Mo and Ov (oxygen vacancy) in 1–10MZ [58,60]. Continue to increase the Mo loading to 20 wt%, the peak shifts back to around 480 °C, but it is an overlap of the two peaks at 440 ℃ and 540 °C after analysis, which are shown in 10MZ_IP. The Mo in bigger Zr(MoO4)2 clusters are more easily reducible compared to that in the Mo-O-Zr structure due to the stronger interaction with Zr. Therefore, the two peaks at 440 and 540 ℃, which are attributed to the reduction of Mo6+ to Mo4+ and Mo4+ to Mo0 in Zr(MoO4)2, respectively [61,62]. As more bigger Zr(MoO4)2 clusters exist in 40MZ, more Mo eventually are reduced to Mo0 showing a strong peak at higher temperature overlapping with the low-temperature reduction peak. This could be one of the reasons for high methane selectivity when the Mo loading increases over 10 wt%, given the higher hydrogen dissociation capability of Mo0 compared to its other oxidation state. XPS analysis was employed to delve into the valence states of Mo-ZrO2 catalysts following reduction. Prior to XPS measurement, in situ reduction was performed, with the outcomes depicted in Fig. 6b-c. For the 10MZ catalyst (without reduction pretreatment), two prominent peaks at 235.8 eV and 233.8 eV are discernible, corresponding to the Mo 3d 3/2 and Mo 3d 5/2 states of Mo6+ species, respectively. The Mo 3d peaks shift towards lower binding energies at 234.7 eV and 231.5 eV after the reduction of 10MZ (noted as 10MZ-R in Fig. 6b), and they correspond to Mo 3d 3/2 and Mo 3d 5/2 of Mo5+ species. And a similar phenomenon appeared for 40MZ-R and 10MZ_IP-R. However, unlike 10MZ-R, besides Mo5+ species, Mo4+ and Mo0 species are observed in 40MZ and 10MZ_IP after reduction pretreatment. This is consistent with the H2-TPR results and demonstrates the sequential reduction of Mo6+ to Mo4+ and further from Mo4+ to Mo0 in Zr(MoO4)2 clusters for 40MZ and 10MZ_IP. As the Mo5+ is the sole species after the reduction of 10MZ based on the observation from XPS, which enables us to use the H2-TPR to validate this observation. The quantitation of H2 consumption was performed using the H2 consumption for CuO reduction as calibration (Figure S12). The H2 consumption for 0.1 g of 10 MZ is 0.12 mmol, matching the stoichiometry H2 requirement of reducing Mo6+ to Mo5+ at 0.135 mmol. Additionally, the XPS spectrum of Zr 3d 5/2 in the reduced 10MZ catalyst shows a binding energy of 182.2 eV, characteristic of the ZrOX species and slightly lower than the Zr 3d 5/2 binding energy in ZrO2 (182.7 eV). This suggests that the reduction process induces oxygen loss from the catalyst. Likewise, the reduction process leads to a decrease in the Mo valence state which inevitably leads to the loss of oxygen and thus the creation of oxygen vacancies, which is also observed in the O1s spectra (Figure S13). Based on the comprehensive findings from Raman spectroscopy, TEM, TPR, and XPS analyses, a schematic representation of the surface structure of Mo-ZrO2 catalysts with varying Mo loadings is included as an inset in Fig. 6a. Using hard template synthesis, when the loading of Mo is no more than 10 wt%, most of Mo will dope into the ZrO2 forming Mo-O-Zr sites highly dispersed on the surface. However, as the loading of Mo increases to or above 20 wt%, or using impregnation synthesis, besides the Mo-O-Zr sites, bigger Zr(MoO4)2 clusters formed. When the Mo loading is less than 10 wt%, the Mo-O-Zr sites density increases with increasing loading maintaining highly dispersed. For the MZ catalysts with the Mo loading at or over 20 wt%, Mo-O-Zr sites agglomerate forming bigger Zr(MoO4)2 clusters. By correlating this structure change and the changes in methanol yield, we speculate that the Mo5+ or Mo5+-Ov-Zr (Ov stands for oxygen vacancy) are active sites for methanol formation during the CO2 hydrogenation over the Mo-ZrO2 catalysts. To test our speculation, based on the formation temperature of Mo5+ around 475 °C obtained from H2-TPR for 10MZ catalyst shown in Fig. 6a, we reduce the catalyst at different temperatures, i.e. 400, 450, 500, and 550 °C, aiming to get the escalating population of Mo5+-Ov-Zr sites, to validate the correlation of methanol yield and Mo5+-Ov-Zr structure. As shown in Fig. 7a, the unreduced 10MZ exhibits a low CO2 conversion and only CO, CH4 in the product. In contrast, methanol appears once the 10MZ gets reduced at 400 °C, which is high enough to reduce the sample to form Mo5+-Ov-Zr sites but its population is still small. The methanol yield continues to increase as the reduction temperature increases until 500 °C, which is the temperature over the temperature to form the Mo5+-Ov-Zr structure (475 ℃). From another side to test our speculation, we examined the Turnover Frequency (TOF) of methanol formation, normalized by the Mo loading, for 1–10MZ. As previously demonstrated, nearly all of the Mo in 1–10MZ forms Mo5+-O-Zr and is exposed on the surface of catalyst. This result is shown in Fig. 7b, the nearly identical TOF of methanol formation further verifies our speculation that the Mo5+-O-Zr is the active site for the methanol formation in Mo-ZrO2 catalysts. This kind of structure with oxygen vacancies was also reported a key role in previous studies. For example, the oxygen vacancies in the In2O3 catalyst act as the active center of the reaction, facilitating the catalytic conversion of CO2 to methanol [26]. The Zr3+−OV−Ga−O species (OV represents the oxygen vacancy) on the GaZrOx catalyst is found as the active site of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. H2 is dissociated on polarized Ga−O sites to produce Ga−H and −OH species, while CO2 is trapped by the oxygen vacancies and activated by electron transfer from the Zr3+ ions [63]. Similarly, the work of Lu [64] et al. demonstrated that the formation of oxygen vacancies at the ZnO1−x/Cu interface promotes optimal binding to H atoms and improves the adsorption of CO2, which in turn generates methanol via the formate pathway. Combining with all the above results, we believe that lower Mo loading preferentially forms Mo-O-Zr on the surface of ZrO2, and Mo5+-Ov-Zr sites are generated after reduction pretreatment and kick off the methanol synthesis. The highly dispersed Mo-O-Zr site can be obtained up to 10 wt% Mo loading when using hard template synthesis, but partially sinters to Zr(MoO4)2 clusters when using impregnation synthesis. As the Mo loading increases over 10 wt%, the Mo-O-Zr sites agglomerate forming Zr(MoO4)2 clusters on the surface of ZrO2 too, and cover more surface of ZrO2 and Mo-O-Zr sites. The reduction of Zr(MoO4)2 clusters generates metallic Mo, which enhances the hydrogen dissociation, thus increasing the methane formation while lowering methanol formation. 4 Conclusions The CO2 hydrogenation reactions over the Mo-ZrO2 catalysts are highly structure-sensitive. Variations in the synthesis method result in distinct surface structures for the Mo-ZrO2 catalysts, thereby leading to different product distributions. The hard template synthesis method incorporates Mo into ZrO2, forming highly dispersed Mo-O-Zr sites on the surface of ZrO2, even at Mo loadings of up to 10 wt%. In contrast, impregnation synthesis at the Mo loading of 10 wt% generates additional sintered Zr(MoO4)2 species. Within the Mo-O-Zr structure, Mo6+ is stabilized by the local environment and can only be reduced to Mo5+ in this experiment, creating an oxygen vacancy (Mo5+-Ov-Zr). However, Mo6+ within the Zr(MoO4)2 can be readily reduced to metallic Mo on the surface of ZrO2. The structures of Mo5+-Ov-Zr and metallic Mo are found to be the primary factors behind the high methanol and methane yields, respectively. The transition of surface species from Mo-O-Zr to Zr(MoO4)2 on ZrO2 alters the product distribution from methanol to methane during CO2 hydrogenation reaction. coredata.dc:description: CO₂ hydrogenation is a structure-sensitive reaction, producing a diverse range of products based on the structure of catalysts. In this study, we present a catalyst Mo-ZrO2 for CO2 hydrogenation and observed the products vary among CO, CH4, and CH3OH as Mo changes in its loading and local environment. Kinetic studies reveal that increasing Mo loading amplifies hydrogenation ability of the catalyst while simultaneously reducing CO2 adsorption on ZrO2. Specifically, Mo loadings under 10 wt% result in Mo integration into ZrO2 support, forming a Mo-O-Zr structure. Conversely, a higher Mo loading leads to the formation of Zr(MoO4)2 clusters on ZrO2 support. The Mo5⁺-Ov-Zr structure, formed in Mo-doped ZrO2 during reduction pretreatment, emerges as an active site for methanol synthesis. In contrast, metallic Mo formed from the reduction of Zr(MoO4)2 clusters loaded on ZrO2 is responsible for methane formation. The evolution of the surface structure from Mo-O-Zr structure to Zr(MoO4)2 clusters on ZrO2 as Mo loading changes, resulting in alterations in the number of active sites for methanol synthesis and methanation, consequently leading to variations in product distribution.
coredata.dc:title: The relationship between structure and performance of Mo-ZrO2 catalysts in CO2 hydrogenation
